reviewText:
I'm a big fan of the 40k universe, though I've never actually played the board game version of Space Hulk.
I've been told it's a very faithful adaptation that plays exactly like the board game. And that's the problem I think...
Like a board game this game is actually rolling dice. Do I hit or miss? How many extra actions do I get? Does my gun jam? Can I get the door to open?
I don't like having all these random factors determine how well I play. It works well for board games, but not so much for a PC game. I have no influence on the outcome of most things. I just place my models and hope for the best.

The Space Marines are (like their armors) incredible clunky to move around. Moving one around a corner and getting him to turn around seems like a chore. Again in a board game I would just pick the model up and place him.

The graphics are nice" but nothing special. Frankly the 3D models looks a little dated. This game has only so many different models and models on screen at a time. I would have preferred a little more attention to polish. You especially notice this in the "action-scenes". The death animations are just sad. That is unacceptable for a game from 2013!

All that being said. Actual gameplay isn't bad per se. I disregard it was ever a board game and judge it on it's own merits. It's pretty exciting to manage your marines with the limited amount of actions each turn. A lot of planning and strategy is involved. It's more like a puzzle game in many ways. And that's it really. This could might as well have been shaved down to a candy themed facebook game!

All in all I give it 4/10
It's okay

reviewText:
I picked up this game during the summer sale because it was cheap, had a cool name, and looked like something that would let an aging gamer have fun without having to train up on fast muscle twich response. It's been all that and more.

Space Hulk is a strategy and tactical game that emphasizes the strategy and tactics without adding lots of gimmicks or complicated options. Random dice rolls keep things a little unpredictable and can make a level easier or harder depending on which way they land. It's similar to other random + skill games like backgammon, cribbage, or other tabletop RPGs. I also liken it to Final Fantasy Tactics, Disgaea, Valkyria Chronicles, and Archon, as far as the importance of unit movement and positioning goes. The downside to its simplicity is that it can be a bit repetitive at times. To help with that, it offers the ability to speed up some of the animation, and later introduces units with different capabilities. The combination of units on any given level are predetermined, which creates different challenges like a limited number of ranged weapons compared to melee or finite ammunition weapons.

I've seen several reviews and comments about the game being too hard and melee combat being nigh impossible (which it kind of is). Many of those players however, seemed to miss key elements of the game, or were trying to play it the wrong way. Much like how open combat must be avoided in the Metal Gear games, melee combat should be avoided in Space Hulk. But that's part of the strategy and tactics. There are several other aspects that a good RTFM takes care of, such as the rules for Genestealer movement, weapon ranges, and automatic weapon unjamming. It's definitely worth a read-through to avoid some frustrations while playing. It can be fun to figure out all the details of the rules through gameplay, but chances are that if you're the strategy/tactical gaming type, you'll eventually want to know all the quirks and check to see what you might have missed.

For me, each level takes about 30 to 60 minutes to play through; YMMV. Once you get the basics down, the relearning curve after putting down the game and coming back to it after a couple days or weeks is minimal. That makes it a great game for a somewhat casual gamer, but I've also given it multi-hour spans and gone through several levels at a time. I frequently forget that you can save the game in the middle of a level, but it just feels wrong to leave one in the middle uncompleted, especially given that 30 to 60 minute timeframe.

Maybe it's just the way I set up my strategies, but most of my play throughs seem to be either dismal failures with perfect storms of consecutive horrible dice rolls against a single point of failure, or 100% clean-sheet victories with multiple redundant safeguards to ensure success. There are a handful of levels where I encountered the middle ground of escaping with half my space marines alive, and those levels are just begging for a replay.

Aside from random elements such as Genestealer spawning and dice rolls, some of the choices that can affect the outcome of a level are: What order should I deploy my units? Should I make a run for it or stand my ground? Will my melee unit be able to hold out long enough to protect my flank in this corridor? Do I have enough command points if my bolter jams and the number of enemies around the corner is 5 and not 3? Should I destroy that door for a longer line of sight, or leave it closed to delay my pursuers? If I turn this corner, will I have enough range to defeat the next wave, and what is the likelihood they will  be able to close to melee range and if so what are my chances of survival? If I lose my flank, will I still be able to clear the level?

You can look to other reviews to cover things like music and graphics and animation; I've no complaints with any of it. If you're looking for a fast-twitch gaming experience or a game where you can just hit attack

reviewText:
Pretty good video game remake of the classic board game. The game did have a few issues earlier, but the development team have been great in supporting the game with regular patches and bug fixes. Game play is pretty good overall, but could use some more cut scenes.

Great DLC at a reasonable price of $5 per dlc. Space Wolves have been recently added, so one can play either them or the blood angels. Looking forward to the rumoured bio-morphs for the genestealers to make them even nastier in MP - heheheh.

Recent patches have added a lobby to the MP side of the game, allowing for greater flexiability in terms of match making.

Graphics aren't the best, and occasionally still glitchy, but the developers are pretty helpful in the forums in terms of feedback and possible solutions.

Space Hulk didnt get the best reviews at launch due to its bugs and glitches, but has greatly improved over the journey, though I would recommend this game to mainly 40K and Space Hulk fans, as some one new to either might be put off by the games earlier 'issues'. If on sale, I would recommend to buy but not if they are still asking around $30.

Rating 7.5/10 for Space Hulk / 40K fans about 6/10 for other parties.

reviewText:
Space Hulk is an odd gaming experience. It's pretty much a pure port of the board game, which is probably the main issue I have with the PC game.
I played the board game about 10 years ago and really enjoyed it, and this is a nice way to play the game if you don't have any humans nearby to play with. But, like chess or monopoly, the human interaction is part of the fun; playing against a computer is...well...souless.

In my opinion, what this game needed was some RPG elements, like gaining experience points to upgrade your squad, or a more engaging storyline. Something to elevate it beyond the boardgame in a way that compensates for that lack of human interaction.
As it is currently, there is no sense of attachment or engagement, which makes the level by level progression of the game feel a little unfulfilling.
The game also feels a bit too unfair - the terminators cannot move very much in a turn, their bolters jam at every oportunity, you have a 1 in 4 chance of winning/surviving close combat, the bolter has a 35% chance of killing in the first shot, and the more reliable weapons have very limited ammo. As far as I can see, your only option is to constantly play defensively: placing your men in key positions and setting them to overwatch" or "guard"; which is difficult when playing an offensive mission.
The odds are against you

reviewText:
Space Hulk is a game that takes place in the Warhammer 40K Universe. Originally, Space Hulk was a board game that was released in the 80s and recieved very high critical acclaim. This success would later on adapt to Warhammer 40K, which has gained a massive following since its inception.

The game has several different campaigns with two of them being DLC. The missions are varied enough from destroying a certain room with a heavy flamer unit, to escort type missions, to even simply destroying the enemy.

The campaigns in Space Hulk follow the Blood Ravens, a chapter of the Space Marines, that are seeking revenge on the genestealers for acts against them nearly seven centuries ago. The genestealers are horrifying monsters with lightning fast movement and can tear through armor as though it were paper.

Although not the best story I've seen in a strategy game, it is adequate enough considering that this game is an adaption of a board game from the 1980s.

Visually, Space Hulk is appealing with its dark, mysterious setting. The Terminators look really cool and are modeled well as if they were Warhammer 40K action figurines themselves. The genestealers also look great and show inspiration from other works such as the Alien franchise. The maps are varied throughout the game and allow the player to play in several to different ways.

The gameplay itself is easy to jump into and plays exactly (from what I've observed) the same as the board game counterpart. You won't even need to look at the rules for Space Hulk as it is easy to just hop in and start playing with your friends or against the computer AI.

The problems. The game plays dreadfully slow even with the speed setting turned up all the way. Space Hulk only allows for most stages to have one or two ways of actually winning, often time with just placing units on overwatch, puppy guarding genestealer spawn points. The only unlockables in the game are used to customize your multiplayer banner, which you will sometimes recieve. It's a 25% chance really if you're playing on normal difficulty.

Space Hulk's developers are very engaged with their community however and I'm sure that within the future, we will see a few changes to Space Hulk and it's gameplay mechanics.

As a video game itself, Space Hulk might be something less than desirable from a strategy enthusiast. It's great adaption however of a classic board game and should be played like a board game. Not like the much more popular Warhammer 40K: Dawn of War series, which is an RTS, but a board game. I would wait for this one to go on sale for less than $20 and then grab it. The $30 isn't really justifiable.

reviewText:
I picked up this game during the summer sale because it was cheap, had a cool name, and looked like something that would let an aging gamer have fun without having to train up on fast muscle twich response. It's been all that and more.

Space Hulk is a strategy and tactical game that emphasizes the strategy and tactics without adding lots of gimmicks or complicated options. Random dice rolls keep things a little unpredictable and can make a level easier or harder depending on which way they land. It's similar to other random + skill games like backgammon, cribbage, or other tabletop RPGs. I also liken it to Final Fantasy Tactics, Disgaea, Valkyria Chronicles, and Archon, as far as the importance of unit movement and positioning goes. The downside to its simplicity is that it can be a bit repetitive at times. To help with that, it offers the ability to speed up some of the animation, and later introduces units with different capabilities. The combination of units on any given level are predetermined, which creates different challenges like a limited number of ranged weapons compared to melee or finite ammunition weapons.

I've seen several reviews and comments about the game being too hard and melee combat being nigh impossible (which it kind of is). Many of those players however, seemed to miss key elements of the game, or were trying to play it the wrong way. Much like how open combat must be avoided in the Metal Gear games, melee combat should be avoided in Space Hulk. But that's part of the strategy and tactics. There are several other aspects that a good RTFM takes care of, such as the rules for Genestealer movement, weapon ranges, and automatic weapon unjamming. It's definitely worth a read-through to avoid some frustrations while playing. It can be fun to figure out all the details of the rules through gameplay, but chances are that if you're the strategy/tactical gaming type, you'll eventually want to know all the quirks and check to see what you might have missed.

For me, each level takes about 30 to 60 minutes to play through; YMMV. Once you get the basics down, the relearning curve after putting down the game and coming back to it after a couple days or weeks is minimal. That makes it a great game for a somewhat casual gamer, but I've also given it multi-hour spans and gone through several levels at a time. I frequently forget that you can save the game in the middle of a level, but it just feels wrong to leave one in the middle uncompleted, especially given that 30 to 60 minute timeframe.

Maybe it's just the way I set up my strategies, but most of my play throughs seem to be either dismal failures with perfect storms of consecutive horrible dice rolls against a single point of failure, or 100% clean-sheet victories with multiple redundant safeguards to ensure success. There are a handful of levels where I encountered the middle ground of escaping with half my space marines alive, and those levels are just begging for a replay.

Aside from random elements such as Genestealer spawning and dice rolls, some of the choices that can affect the outcome of a level are: What order should I deploy my units? Should I make a run for it or stand my ground? Will my melee unit be able to hold out long enough to protect my flank in this corridor? Do I have enough command points if my bolter jams and the number of enemies around the corner is 5 and not 3? Should I destroy that door for a longer line of sight, or leave it closed to delay my pursuers? If I turn this corner, will I have enough range to defeat the next wave, and what is the likelihood they will  be able to close to melee range and if so what are my chances of survival? If I lose my flank, will I still be able to clear the level?

You can look to other reviews to cover things like music and graphics and animation; I've no complaints with any of it. If you're looking for a fast-twitch gaming experience or a game where you can just hit attack

reviewText:
There's a better free game (Alien Assault) which, although 2D, does a better job at drawing you in. The developers of Space Hulk should play that and find out how this genre should be done.

Space Hulk itself is OK. Glitches (bullets firing into the void instead of down corridors, sometimes camera panning going in weird directions) and funky controls (click/drag to change direction can be easily accidentally triggered, especially when trying to move 1 sq forward/back, and ridiculously sensitive camera controls) take away from the experience.

The 3D graphics just aren't that good. The marines look OK, but the genestealers look like kids toys and the general quality is more 2003 than 2013. The graphics themselves make the game mechanics look stupid. Bullet trails passing through a corridor of enemies but only rolling against the first is an example.

In AA your marines persist between missions, increasing in rank and receiving awards. The 2D graphics are much more to the point and easier to interact with. The UI is vastly more intuitive and quicker to work with. It's just a better game even though it has the same mechanics. Space Hulk is not worth the full price (19.99 at time of review). Only consider buying it at a discount.

reviewText:
I'll make this short:

The good stuff:
+ the gameplay itself is good
+ the graphics are more than adequate
+ the sound effects are actually well-done; every weapon sounds as powerful as you'd expect

BUT, and that's a big one:
- the key binds are still not configurable, even after months of players begging for this feature.


Seriously? This is 2014. A PC game with non-configurable controls, even if it is a turn-based tactics game, is a huge no-go.

So unless - or rather until - this is fixed, I can not, in good conscience, recommend this game; not even at budget price.

Space Hulk is an odd gaming experience. It's pretty much a pure port of the board game, which is probably the main issue I have with the PC game.
I played the board game about 10 years ago and really enjoyed it, and this is a nice way to play the game if you don't have any humans nearby to play with. But, like chess or monopoly, the human interaction is part of the fun; playing against a computer is...well...souless.

In my opinion, what this game needed was some RPG elements, like gaining experience points to upgrade your squad, or a more engaging storyline. Something to elevate it beyond the boardgame in a way that compensates for that lack of human interaction.
As it is currently, there is no sense of attachment or engagement, which makes the level by level progression of the game feel a little unfulfilling.
The game also feels a bit too unfair - the terminators cannot move very much in a turn, their bolters jam at every oportunity, you have a 1 in 4 chance of winning/surviving close combat, the bolter has a 35% chance of killing in the first shot, and the more reliable weapons have very limited ammo. As far as I can see, your only option is to constantly play defensively: placing your men in key positions and setting them to overwatch" or "guard"; which is difficult when playing an offensive mission.
The odds are against you
date: you will lose often (even in the early missions) and it will start to become boring after a while since it is a machine beating you
recommended: and not your buddy who you can laugh with afterwards. You also can't switch and play as the Genestealers in the campaign
hoursPlayed: so you are stuck as the lumbering terminators with unreliable weapons.\n\nIn short - if you want to play the Space Hulk board game alone

reviewText:
I played the hardcopy boardgame years ago and this is a great computer-based representation of that. Does a very good job of capturing the 40k feel and visual aesthetic.

As far as gameplay goes, it winds up as more of a puzzle game than a tactical game, but it's a very fun one, and the randomness introduced by the dice rolling means that you'll get a variation on the challenge every time.

The graphics are not bad at all and run well on a variety of machines. Overall a fun and worthwhile purchase.

UPDATE 09-2015:
Since I wrote my original review above, I've acquired the recently released 4th edition of the boardgame. Happy to confirm (as others have noted previously) that this video game is indeed a very excellent translation of the boardgame to digital format. Rules for movement, shooting, line of sight, etc. are identical, the Sin of Damnation missions are lifted largely from the missions provided in the boardgame rulebook, etc. etc. Considering the boardgame is well over $100 US, it makes this game a bargain by comparison for those wanting a genuine Space Hulk experience.

The biggest critique is that the Genestealer AI isn't as devious as an experienced human opponent can be. This can be avoided by playing hotseat or via MP (although at this point the servers are pretty dead) but it's not the end of the world - the levels are still fun puzzles to sort through, and for my part anyways I find it a fun challenge to try to finish them without losing a single Space Marine.

I've finished the Sin of Damnation campaign and intended to play through the rest of the DLC soon. The extra levels and skins provided are cool, I would really love to see more offered (especially Dark Angels Deathwing Space Marines and corresponding levels & weapons) but it's looking pretty unlikely.

Summary: if you want to experience Space Hulk 4th edition in digital format, this is an affordable and beautiful option. I don't regret the purchase at all and look forward to coming back to this game for years to come, whenever I need a fix.

reviewText:
Space Hulk , such a tremendous game within the tabletop wargamin society. The video game however? That is up for debate.
As a person who has never played the table top version of this game, I'm somewhat on a mid point opinion about the video game itself. It being a Warhammer 40k game, sure made me interested to buy it. But the gameplay itself?
The gameplay takes its roots from the table top version, as in, everything is decided by the dice roller. This offcourse can lead to massive ammounts of RAGE , when a unit of yours misses a door, in front of which it is standing of (literally, one tile away), more than one time, which can cause you to miss the entire turn for that unit, and any unit standing behind it (offcourse, when I say door, I mean on one of those mailfunctioning doors that need to be shot open, or knocked open). This can really screw up whatever strategy you might have come up with , which can increase the difficulty, or just make you have to replay the mission/game from the start.
Concerning strategy, the game itself is placed within a Space Hulk (for those that do not know what that is, it's a massive, ancient, space ship, that is filled with tiny corridors (atleast for your Terminators (Space Marines with extremely special suits))). And this is the part what the game does really well, it really makes you feel claustrophobic. Terminators are slow, sluggish, bulky, and the corridors are really really small, wheareas genestealers are fast, agile, and come in large numbers. If you dont cover all accesses , you are going to get slaughtered in close combat. And loosing even a single Terminator can pretty much change the game outcome, whereas genestealers just keep coming and coming. But then again, if you zone in on the genestealer spawn zones, you are going to spend your game watching a cluster , watching the same kill cam cinematic over and over.
The graphics are not anything special, theyre really lame , especially if you compare it with DoW 2 graphics. Animations are simplistic, literally 2-3 animations that just keep going on, and on, and on. But, atleast the character details are done well, the Terminators especially. BUT, Voice acting is awfull. Just awfull. You will hear one voice, with the same tone, throughout the entire game. Hello? We used to play DoW 1 and 2, and them both had great voice acting, so why limit us with such horrible voice acting in Space Hulk? I would have done a better job with Audacity. And even the sound effects in this game are stuttering, buggy, and sometimes even missing out. But that will probably/hopefully be patched with time.
SIngle Player will get repetitive, and booring, after a while. The multiplayer however, mixes things up, because youre going up against another player, and in my opinion, a players intelligence > an artificial intelligence. And, there is some customization to be done, to the banner especially. But then again, who cares about banners?
In the end, this isnt a very good game. I'd give it a 6 out of 10, JUST because im a Warhammer 40k fan. I'd reccomend this game only to players who like the gameplay, and can cope with the lame graphics, effects, sounds, and pretty much everything else that isnt the gameplay itself. To everyone else, if youre looking for a similar game, go purchase XCOM: Enemy Unknown, or whatever the exact name was of that game that came out last year or so~
To those (like me) who purchased this game, enjoy the game, and the multiplayer, for now, and hope for patches, and more content through the ingame(or well Steam) shop for DLC's, and/or expansions.

reviewText:
I have LOVED the Warhammer: 40,000 series all my life and own all of the strategy games (still looking to pickup the Space Marine + laning spinoff).

The squad based style of Space Hulk is very easy to pickup if you have played strategy/squad-based games before. The learning curve is very reasonable and there are a multitude of difficulties you can choose, however, the game can still be very difficult. The game is all about dice rolls, so if you like D&D-style pen&paper mechanics, this game is for you. That being said, it is very easy for your Terminators to be one-shot killed by the enemy in melee situations.

Aesthetics are grim and repetitive at times, but still nice to look at. There is a cool function where a front-cam is applied to each of your squad members, and you can see what they see as they move.

Overall, I would recommend this game.

reviewText:
I am unimpressed.  Yes, this is a faithful adaptation of the 1989 board game, right down to telling you exactly what the Space Marines and Genestealers rolled on their six-sided dice each turn.  And that's a problem.

Movement grids, turns and six-sider-based combat mechanics are all  useful approaches to creating a game that can be run on the limited processing power available in a group of human players.  On a computer that could do so much more, it just seems rather pitiful.  The grid based movement and action point system make your tactical options very limited while the randomness of the six-sider engine ensures that even an optimal strategy can be overwhelmed in one or two turns of bad (simulated) rolls.  (And, conversely, sloppy strategy can still triumph, if the dice favour you.)

In the original game, seeing your squad crushed without recourse because the dice simply turned against you was an accepted part of play.  Playing with a group, seeing a friend suddenly get demolished by a run of bad luck could be a source of hilarity.  But playing solo, in a computer game that didn't need to rely on something as crude as a handful of d6s, allowing victory or defeat to lie in the hands of virtualized plastic cubes seems inexcusably lazy.

The setting is cool.  The graphics and sound are adequate.  But the mechanics of the board game needed a major overhaul to make the transition to a digital environment, and they didn't get it.

reviewText:
A very fun strategy game. It may seem strange at first, but it has a very good atmosphere, and mechanics. It compares to the Classic Xcom games where you have a certain amount of action points that you try to get the most out of. On the surface Space Hulk seems very shallow, but the simple mechanics get more and more complex as the game moves on, and you field different soilders. This game will kick you in the nuts, and thenrip off your head while you are down. It is brutal. The multiplayer is fun, but slightly unbalanced for the terminators. I always have my terminatorsso close to victory, to then have an anticlimactic finish.

Overall Space Hulk is a fantastic turn based strategy game for one player, but the multiplayer mode is a little unbalanced. You need to try this game if you consider yourself a strategy gamer. This game will kick you in the nuts, and then rip off your head while you are down. It is brutal.
9/10

reviewText:
The interface for this game is pretty bad. Its often hard to tell which character you have selected, and once you click on a square to move them to, there is no way to cancel it, or even shift to another square of movement. There is no indication of which characters have already activated unless you click on them, which can result in accidental movement.

The animations and sound effects are cheap and extremely limited and repetitious . The graphics feel really dated for a company like games workshop, who have a lot of money to make this look great. I guess they went with the budget plan instead.

The game itself is pretty boring. The game basically breaks down to moving really really slowly down choked corridors and rolling 5+ over and over again. In the 2 hours I played I found no strategy whatsoever in the choices I was making, and the mechanics being really frustrating and limited. I have contemplated several times buying the board game, and am now really glad I never did. That would have been a $90 mistake. Glad I got this version on the cheap to warn me off.

If you want a good turn based stategy on PC go play X-Com. And if you want a good turn based stategy on the tabletop, the Gears of War boardgame blows this garbage out of the water.

reviewText:
It's a faithful port of the Space Hulk boardgame.  Not the Warhammer 40,000 tabletop strategy game - just plain ol' Space Hulk.

If you're not familiar with Space Hulk...  It was a spin-off from Warhammer 40,000.  It featured Space Marine Terminators making their way through cramped corridors and fighting Tyranid Genestealers.  Heavily turn-based.  Very slow-paced.  Not a whole lot in the line of character development or depth.  Think of it kind of like a 40k version of chess

The videogame does a good job of porting that to the computer, while updating the visuals to match what we've become accustomed to with recent Warhammer 40,000 releases.

It's still a slow-paced game.  Still heavily turn-based.  There's not much you customization or character development.  There isn't a whole lot of storyline.  You've got Terminators plodding through cramped corridors and killing Genestealers - just like the boardgame.

If you've enjoyed the boardgame and you're looking for something you can play solo, you'll probably be pretty happy with Space Hulk.

If you've been enjoying the other Warhammer 40,000 offerings on Steam and you're looking for your next hit, you'll probably be disappointed with Space Hulk.

reviewText:
I wouldn't recommend this game unless you enjoyed the board game version of it.

I understand that the passionates for the board games rate this one pretty good. I played space crusade on board some time ago and I was expecting something like that, that could entertain me as a tactic strategy gamer. Despite being a DoW fanboy I found this game more focused on luck than on skill.

The corridors have one man wide, which could be as in the original, but cripples the chance of positioning an to cover your troops with other troops (like in chess), and this is needed because the weapons stuck 1/6 of the time. If that happend, when a genstealer manages to reach a regular troops, they are mostly dead. They could parry a hit or two, but the genstealers have a big amount of points to spend them on mele attacks. Your comander could survive a couple of hits, but its mostly dead the next turn also.

I find it unforgiving because a tiny error in positioning can make you restart the level, but unlike XCom, I find this game cruel because everything can go wrong despite being doing a flawless strategy. That being said, I particularly don't enjoy the games where the hp of my troops are in binary (alive and death), so I enjoyed more Talisman, Bloodbowl (despite knowing barely the rules also) and Aarklash legacy (this one is not from GW but the french company rackham, which owns Confrontation) than this game. And about a tactic turn based game, XCom is as unforgiving as this one, but you have more tools to avoid being brutally murdered.

More things about the game: You can customize the look of your chapter through unlocking new stuff everytime you beat a mission. I also read in the reviews that the game looks unfinished, so clarify that a couple of weeks before the launch of the game I saw a video where they confess that they didn't finish the animations yet. OST is good, but the sounds may sound repetitive. The menus are fluent and cool. The intros for the missions are pretty apealing, because you can see the terrain you are going to fight in, with a voice talking about why you need to do that mission and marking you the important points. Brilliant inmersion wise.

reviewText:
I'm not a huge 40K fan, although I do enjoy the universe they've created.  I've tried Space Marine, which had some really good qualities, but ultimately was a fairly large failure of a game.  I've tried Dawn of War II, and enjoyed it, but it doesn't feel that much like a Warhammer game - it's more of a strategy game with warhammer skinning.  Not that that's a bad thing - it's a very good strategy game (at least, in my opinion), but it doesn't really capture the flavor of 40K.

Space Hulk, on the other hand, manages to take a lot of what makes 40K special - the bleakness, the fight against overwhelming odds - and capture that essence pretty damn well.  This comes in part due to the fact that it's pretty much a straight reimaging of the board game of the same name, but that doesn't make it any less fun.  In fact, one of the reasons I'm enjoying it so much is that the Board Game takes while to set up, and requires 2 people to play.  It can be great fun, but despite owning the board game for a few years now, I don't think I've played it more than twice.  Maybe three times.  This game, however, has already gotten me more play time, and I've been able to see more missions than I ever have on the board game.  And the board game cost $100 - AND you're lucky to find it these days - it was a limited run printing.

This game pits you as the commander of a squad of space marines against a hoarde of aliens - sound familiar?  In fact, the original game was inspired by the movie Alien & Aliens.  Anyway, you command your squad to objectives - enter a room, kill everything, retrieve some artifact - and then see how well you pit your skills against the oncoming alien horde.  And horde is correct - unless there's a specific kill X genestealers (the aliens) to win" objective

reviewText:
I'm not a huge 40K fan, although I do enjoy the universe they've created.  I've tried Space Marine, which had some really good qualities, but ultimately was a fairly large failure of a game.  I've tried Dawn of War II, and enjoyed it, but it doesn't feel that much like a Warhammer game - it's more of a strategy game with warhammer skinning.  Not that that's a bad thing - it's a very good strategy game (at least, in my opinion), but it doesn't really capture the flavor of 40K.

Space Hulk, on the other hand, manages to take a lot of what makes 40K special - the bleakness, the fight against overwhelming odds - and capture that essence pretty damn well.  This comes in part due to the fact that it's pretty much a straight reimaging of the board game of the same name, but that doesn't make it any less fun.  In fact, one of the reasons I'm enjoying it so much is that the Board Game takes while to set up, and requires 2 people to play.  It can be great fun, but despite owning the board game for a few years now, I don't think I've played it more than twice.  Maybe three times.  This game, however, has already gotten me more play time, and I've been able to see more missions than I ever have on the board game.  And the board game cost $100 - AND you're lucky to find it these days - it was a limited run printing.

This game pits you as the commander of a squad of space marines against a hoarde of aliens - sound familiar?  In fact, the original game was inspired by the movie Alien & Aliens.  Anyway, you command your squad to objectives - enter a room, kill everything, retrieve some artifact - and then see how well you pit your skills against the oncoming alien horde.  And horde is correct - unless there's a specific kill X genestealers (the aliens) to win" objective

reviewText: Although certainly not worth full retail price, Space Hulk is an extremely enjoyable game of tactics that aims to directly replicate the board game. With combat that resembles a more claustrophobic XCOM, you will find yourself leading a squadron (or two) of Space Marine Terminators, some of the heaviest infantry units in the Galaxy, through narrow tyranid infested corridors. Every movement may compromize the safety of your squad and will be done so tactfully.\n\nI got this game for under $2 and it was a great investment, I wish I would have purchased the DLC while it was also on sale. This game is far from a full $30 package and Games Workshop is absurd to charge such a price for it (averaging around $50 with all DLC at retail value), but if you're a Warhammer 40k or XCOM fan and find this game on sale for under $5, it's certainly worth a spin.

reviewText:
Sry, I am a total Space Hulk  and Warhammer 40k and I'm just not impressed with the gameplay. Too much like a board game (I know it's roots so don't flame me, plz). I played Space Hulk on the Commodore Amiga and I liked it for it's play style: I would plan my movement and actions of my Terminators and the AI would plan for the Genestealers...but we both executed our moves at the same time and  I could actually control any one of my terminators! HUGE difference fighting for your life face to face with a Genestealer, lopping the top of their skulls off or, blood flying all over the inside of your helmet and you realize you are doomed BUT, if your Terminator has the heavy flamer, he can blow himself up and take nine squares (and anything in those squares) up in a conflagration of fire!
Yeah, to me, this game doesn't have none of that. Can't fault the devs, they made SH beautiful and not one crash. For anyone who loves the board game, you may love it. For anyone who played SH on the Amiga, pray that one of the dev's come across it and copies it's gameplay.

I would give it a C" for atmosphere and gameplay.

I know it's clice' but

reviewText:
A loyal and accurate adaption of the 3rd Edition (from memory) rules version of the Space Hulk boardgame, with only minor rules adjustment to allow for better playability on a PC platform.

The Metacritic score does not do this game justice, simply as the negative, and even many of the mixed reviews, unfairly criticise Space Hulk for not being a faster and more 'arcadey' turn-based strategy, along the lines of XCom : Enemy Unknown/Within. This was never the intention, instead, Full Control's faithful recreation of the classic boardgame is in fact one of Space Hulk's greatest strengths to a true Space Hulk fan.

Genestealers, the environments, and each individual terminator, are rendered in intricate detail, right down to Terminators being adorned with swinging scolls and battle honours, along with realistic lighting and shading effects on terrain and units. Both Terminators and Genestealers are fully animated and life-like in their movements, and these animations are accompanied by fantastic audio and a fitting sound track.

A faithful and beautifully designed recreation of the original Space Hulk. I'd recommend it to any true fan.

reviewText:
Slow and boring

This is a digital version of the Games Workshop board game of the same name.

You play as a chapter of Blood Angel Space Marines trying to retake a city sized ship form Tyranids (think zerg or xenomorph).

the game is broken up into various scenarios and has you sending in a squad of space marines into narrow hallways to acomplish various objectives (like kill a certain tyranid or save somebody or hold an area for set nubers of turns)  the game is turn based with you spending action points to move and fight each turn.  depending on the scenario you can choose the types of marines and there equipment at the start of the level.

This all sounds well in good but in pratice all your doing is slowlying moving a group of guys that look like refrigerators with legs down tight hallways and slowly trading blows with generic looking bug aliens.  wether you succed or die in combat is determened by an off screen dice roll so you'll move a guy up to a bug.  they's slash you'll shoot (unless you have a sword or hammer) and one of you will fall down. thats most of the game and its as boring as it sounds.

If your a 40k fan then i recommend the dawn of war games, if you want a squad based sci-fi tactics game i recommend shadow runner returns (or pratically anything else)  The only thing this game has going for it is that is way cheaper than the actual board game.

reviewText: I generally love 40k games and I was so surprised at how much I hated this one. Compared to every other entry in the series it's slow, clunky, frustrating, and really more a matter of luck than skill. Unless you're prepared to play a map several times to figure out the enemy spawn patterns and other random BS that the game will do, I wouldn't recommend it.\n\nThe DLC's are a blatant money grab and the sheer number of them should be off-putting to anyone with common sense. Unless you love the actual Space Hulk board game or yearn for the days when games would be unfairly difficult just to squeeze quarters out of arcade gamers, I recommend passing on this one.

reviewText:
tl;dr: If you like warhammer or strategy; don't even think about buying it, even if it is so ridiculously cheap. Go get a soda instead.

Review:
Honestly... I have been craving space hulk since it came out, thinking OMFG this is nice.

The story of the game is pretty lacking, but then again so was the original board game.
What ticks me off, is the chance to hit, the lack of strategy, the horrible control method and the fact that in the tutorial my guys die in 1 hit from the enemy, and the specific mission no matter how i tried, they were gonna take a hit.

There is most likely a way to finish it, but it gives you two space marines versus atleast 15 randomly generated and positioned tyrranids. The first guy is placed behind a broken door and if I destroy the door in order to move i'll be much closer to atleast one of the xenos beasts, and even if i manage to take out the first 3 or 4 the 5th is going to take me out.  So i decided not to destroy the door. Figured, let the tyrranids do it and then i'll be waiting there with my massive gun.

My guy missed the tyrranid with a freaking storm bolter on a distance less than 2 meters away, tyrranid steps in and one hits my terminator. I tried this mission 3 or 4 times and then i just gave up. There were no other alternatives to what i did, there was just too much random chance in the matter.

Strategy != random chance. you may have some random elements or procedurally generated content to make the game renewable and interesting.. But in this game it is really all about getting lucky.

conclusion: not interesting and just horribly made.

reviewText:
It's a carbon copy of the Games Workshop board game. They advertised it as such, and made no attempt to mislead. In that respect, this is a pretty good game. The campaign and maps, and squads are exactly the same as the board game that GW re-released a few years ago. having it in a digital formatt allows me to play it with friends where I normally couldn't. Like the ones that have moved. It's D6 based, enemies spawn in the same fashion as they do in the board game... This is an exact digital copy. Yes, I've said that previously. I'm stressing that point because almost all the negative reviews seem to have missed that entirely.

This is targeted at fans of the Games Worshop line up. Not necessarily fans of the video games made under their license.

If you liked the board game, you'll like this. If you like turn based strategy, you may also like this. If your a fan of the Warhammer 40k table top game, you may find this amusing as well.

You prolly wont enjoy this if... You like fast paced, twitch reflex games. Are only getting it because it has the GW logo. Getting it because your only experience with Warhammer 40k is the video games(that isn't a bash). This is not a 40k video game like Dawn of War, or Space Marine. This is closer to Blood Bowl, which is also a digital remake of a GW board game.

7.5/10 as a turnbased, squad strategy.
10/10 if you're a fan of the board game.

reviewText:
I'm a huge fan of tabletop games, although never got into Warhammer 40k in particular (I was more into Legions of Steel, which has much in common with the Space Hulk board game as it turns out).  I first played the PC version of Space Hulk back in the mid-90s, and it immediately addicted me with its puzzle-like levels and brutal, unforgiving gameplay.  I originally grabbed this title purely due to my desire for an update.  It was a bit buggy at release; however, it's been cleaned up dramatically and is now quite solid IMO.

It does take a while to get used to the way you have to deploy and move your squad.  Some complaints you'll see about randomness is likely the result of someone not getting this completely under their belt.  I can also see people's point about wanting some kind of development over time for your squad members, but I'll admit I prefer the more puzzle-like format of the missions keeping you focused on your objective, and sometimes Terminators will fall in pursuit of it.  If there was xp-based leveing up of your squad, many people will just save-scum to ensure progression rather than focus on the puzzle at hand.

If you're a fan of turn-based squad combat or table-top wargames, and crave some challenge, I would imagine Space Hulk would fit the bill for you nicely.

reviewText: This game is so much better than the Metascore would indicate. I think a lot of the negativity is due to the numerous bugs that were in the game when launched. They seemed to have fixed/improved all the major issues. That said, it is one of the best games I have played on Steam since Portal 2. I preface this by saying that I was a huge fan of the original board game and prefer turn-based strategy to real-time.  The early missions are pretty simplistic with limited options for your crew. But get deeper into the missions--especially with the DLC missions, and you're in for a treat. The sense of claustrophobia and panic when things go wrong is very well conveyed. The addition of psychics, chain guns and the Wolf marines really adds a lot of different strategies and to the overall awesomeness of the game. The game itself has a great look generally, although the cut-scene animations where you waste the genestealers look pretty cheesy. The game is reasonably priced as are the DLC missions.  Highly recommended to fans of the board game or Warhammer 40K fanboys.

reviewText: I'm a longtime fan of Space Hulk (my dad raised me on the board game), so this was a must have for me. Couldn't really recommend it beyond that, though. I grabbed it on sale at $4.99 - probably wouldn't have, otherwise, despite my fandom. If you're reading this outside of sale season, just be patient and wait for it to drop like I did. The visuals are dated and the animations are repetitive, and I would have liked to see more cinematics, but that's not a huge turn-off, considering the price. This is, simply put, an extremely faithful digital reproduction of the classic board game. The AI is on point, but the difficulty ramp is fraking steep and the random number generator produces 1s at what seems to be a statistically anomolous rate. If I had d6s roll the way they do in this game I'd have thrown them away by now. Anyway, fun way to get my fix when I can't con my friends into playing the board game, and if you're a Space Hulk or tabletop 40k fan, go ahead and pick it up. If you're looking for something faster-paced in the 40k universe I'd recommend Dawn of War 1 and 2 (if you're looking for RTS) or Space Marine if you're more the shooty type.

reviewText: In the Grim dark future there is only jammed storm bolters. The emperor has forsaken you, the machine spirits will not answer your prayers. Within this dark corridor on this jumbled broken mass of wrecked starships, the product of ten millennia of war, there is barely the room to turn around. You can hear the bark of your battle brothers storm bolters before they click silent, misfiring once again, then you hear the screams. They are all around you, coming through every hole and down every corridor. It is too many, they are too fast. Perhaps with your brothers at your back, maybe if you see them comming there is a chance. You have already killed so many, stained so much plasteel with xenos blood, but how much longer before your storm bolter too finally goes silent? What help can your brothers lend when the enemy is upon you? You will die here.\n\nAnd when you awake you will find the same dark halls filled with the echos of xenos footsteps coming for you. Once again you will wander through this unforgiving labyrinth looking for an escape you never find. Perhaps this time, you are so close now.

reviewText:
The Good: Seems like a very faithful recreation of the board game, which I have always wanted to play and never had the opportunity. So you get the board game without a lot of the niggly details that come from setting up a board game, making sure you understand the rules, and finding another player to play against (though you still need to do this if you choose to play multiplayer). If you like strategy board games with dice rolls, this is definitely worthwhile to check out. The graphics are nice. Sound f/x and voice acting, all top notch.

SIDENOTE: I see some of the reviews and it seems like they want so much more than what this ever tried to be, which is an adaptation of the board game. That's why I bought this. If they had made a bunch of needless changes, it becomes less and less what it should be. If you want some other game, say, XCom, there's nothing wrong with that, but if you want XCom, go buy XCom.

The Bad: It will never fully replicate the feeling of rolling dice yourself, but that's a small loss. What bugs me about this game is that you are paying for about half of the game. And then you have to pay for the rest of the missions and you can't even access different 'chapters', yet the option is so clearly staring you in the face on the main menu locked. As much as I enjoy this game and the Warhammer 40k universe (and especially the Dawn of War series, which doesn't do this), this just rubs me the wrong way. At least have an alternate chapter you can access and then have additional chapters to purchase, if you will, so it doesn't quite seem like you are selling me an incomplete game.

Same with the additional campaigns that are there, staring you in the face with a lock symbol. At least don't put them there until after you buy them as DLC. Maybe include a DLC section, like many games, so that they remain separate and apart.

I know the DLC culture that game companies have embraced is the thing now, but I rather loathe it. I tend to wait until much later, so I can buy the most complete version of the game right off the bat (often the 'game of the year' edition).

LAST WORD: If you like Warhammer 40k and/or if you like board games, check this one out. My complaints really don't win out over what I enjoy about this game.

reviewText: A largely-faithful recreation of the boardgame, and as such it plays like a boardgame. Your squad(s) and their loadouts are preselected based on the mission, and gameplay is centered around managing Action Points and a variable pool of Command Points, with additional resource management required when dealing with assault cannons and heavy flamers (both of which have limited ammunition). If the odds are in your favor you can park Sargeant Gideon and his impressively large hammer in a chokepoint and watch as he stomps 14 Genestealers in a single game. If the odds are not in your favor you'll watch him go down to the first melee attack launched against him.\n\nIf you are looking for a fully featured 40K experience this is not it and it is not meant to be. On the other hand if you're a fan of the Space Hulk boardgame, or of boardgames in general, then this game is certainly worth giving a whirl.

reviewText:
What is your life?
My honour is my life.
What is your fate?
My duty is my fate.
What is your fear?
My fear is to fail.
What is your reward?
My salvation is my reward.
What is your craft?
My craft is death.
What is your pledge?
My pledge is eternal service

No other words are necessary, my Brothers. Purge thy mind of all doubt, place this amusement construct into thine cart and purchase it without hesitation or remorse. Though the Adeptus Mechanicus has labored long and well, no construct is without fault and even the most sacred relic might fail in the searing crucible of battle. Fear not; the Machine Spirits will answer your prayers. The blasphemy of the Tyranids is such that only one solution is acceptable. Extermination.

Know what you're buying before you click the button. This game is exactly what it says it is, nothing more. It is exactly what I wanted, and I'm really enjoying it. If you like the WH40k universe, you are more likely to be forgiving of any perceived shortcomings. It is a digital reproduction of a boardgame; if you don't like boardgames or their mechanics, you might not like this. There are dice rolls, meaning luck is involved. If that bothers you, perhaps this game is not for you. It is turn based, meaning planning and tactical thought are essential to victory. This game is about close quarters battle in very confined spaces. This results in a very particular style of play which may not appeal to everyone. Tension is only elevated and enhanced by the element of randomness and luck. Your opinion may differ, if so....I think you already know the answer.

Put yourself in the mindset of a Space Marine. You are not failing if you lose Marines. If the objective is accomplished by the last man, victory is yours. Space Marines are supposed to die, they expect to die. Get out of the mindset of preserving your squad...the deaths do not carry over to the next mission. If a Marine holds a corridor alone and ends up overwhelmed, but in so doing bought enough time for the mission to be accomplished? Victory. Preserve your strength if you can, but do not be afraid to spend the lives of your Marines if it leads to victory. Fear only failure.

Look to your battle gear and it will protect you.
We guard it with our lives.
As your armour guards your life.
As it has my fallen brethren.
Honour the craft of death.
We serve only the Emperor.
Honour the battle gear of the dead.
We ask only to serve.

reviewText:
This game is a very close recreation of the Space Hulk board game.  If you enjoy the board game (or could not find a copy of the 3rd edition version) this is an excellent purchase that I fully recommend.

If you have not played Space Hulk, but like Warhammer 40K, I also recommend this game for the atmosphere.  So far the game seems to capture the feel of 40K pretty well.  It is kind of like the Dawn of War series in that regard, but focused solely on Terminators and Genestealers.  Hopefully they will expand the game in the future using other units and/or races from 40K (which were given some rules in old White Dwarf articles.)

If you don't know about warhammer 40K or Space Hulk, this is still a very good squad based game.  It is turn based, which until recently had been hard to find.  While I believe something like XCOM is a better turn based squad game, this one is also quite good, but limited compared to that game.  There in not advancement, force management, or other features.  This is pure turn based mission execution.

Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone interested in a turn based squad game.  However, Warhammer 40K fans and those that know and love the Space Hulk board game will be the most impressed with it.

reviewText:
What is your life?
My honour is my life.
What is your fate?
My duty is my fate.
What is your fear?
My fear is to fail.
What is your reward?
My salvation is my reward.
What is your craft?
My craft is death.
What is your pledge?
My pledge is eternal service

No other words are necessary, my Brothers. Purge thy mind of all doubt, place this amusement construct into thine cart and purchase it without hesitation or remorse. Though the Adeptus Mechanicus has labored long and well, no construct is without fault and even the most sacred relic might fail in the searing crucible of battle. Fear not; the Machine Spirits will answer your prayers. The blasphemy of the Tyranids is such that only one solution is acceptable. Extermination.

Know what you're buying before you click the button. This game is exactly what it says it is, nothing more. It is exactly what I wanted, and I'm really enjoying it. If you like the WH40k universe, you are more likely to be forgiving of any perceived shortcomings. It is a digital reproduction of a boardgame; if you don't like boardgames or their mechanics, you might not like this. There are dice rolls, meaning luck is involved. If that bothers you, perhaps this game is not for you. It is turn based, meaning planning and tactical thought are essential to victory. This game is about close quarters battle in very confined spaces. This results in a very particular style of play which may not appeal to everyone. Tension is only elevated and enhanced by the element of randomness and luck. Your opinion may differ, if so....I think you already know the answer.

Put yourself in the mindset of a Space Marine. You are not failing if you lose Marines. If the objective is accomplished by the last man, victory is yours. Space Marines are supposed to die, they expect to die. Get out of the mindset of preserving your squad...the deaths do not carry over to the next mission. If a Marine holds a corridor alone and ends up overwhelmed, but in so doing bought enough time for the mission to be accomplished? Victory. Preserve your strength if you can, but do not be afraid to spend the lives of your Marines if it leads to victory. Fear only failure.

Look to your battle gear and it will protect you.
We guard it with our lives.
As your armour guards your life.
As it has my fallen brethren.
Honour the craft of death.
We serve only the Emperor.
Honour the battle gear of the dead.
We ask only to serve.

reviewText:
Supposedly, the Imperium sends Terminators to delve deep into the twisted masses of derelicts known as Space Hulks because only they are strong enough to face the horrors within.

Given the life expectancy of Terminators in this game, regular Space Marines must spontaneously combust the moment they breath space hulk air.

This game is an extremely faithful recreation of the original board game. Don't go into this expecting an epic story (For the record, the story: Space Hulk filled with bad things. Here are many guns. Go kill now.), an action-packed thrill-a-minute roller coaster, or a graphical tour-de-force. Sometimes a mission will be failed because the dice hate you and your Seargeant can't hit the broad side of a genestealer and your guns jam after every shot. Sometimes you'll realize too late that the guy with the flamethrower is at the back of the troop column marching single file through the dark corridors. And sometimes you'll win.

Either way, go into this game with the right expectations and you'll be well rewarded. For instance, remember that, like the board game it's based on, Space Hulk is best taken in two to three hours sessions, not marathons.

reviewText:
Meh. A bit of a retro take on the 40K IP. Apparently, Space Hulk was one of the original Warhammer 40k board games, and was released in 1989. I can't be sure (having never played the board game), but I bet this PC version is exactly like it.

In a departure from recent entries into the W40K series of games, Space Hulk goes back to the game's turn-based roots. I don't know if anybody remembers Chaos Gate, but this feels a lot like that. You deploy a handful of Space Marine Terminators (for those not familiar with 40K, a Terminator is a decorated veteran Space Marine that gets to wear huger armor and is therefore able to carry even blammier weapons) to undertake missions against swarms of Tyranid Genestealers.

As far as gameplay, there's not a lot of variety, and absolutely nothing innovative or unique. This is essentially the same as the old Fallout series. The different missions keep things interesting enough, but the fact that there is just the one type of enemy is a bit of a let-down. Don't get me wrong; it's fun to mow down hordes of Genestealers. But it gets old. It would be nice to throw in the ocassional... I dunno. something else.

The tactics of the game are fairly straightforward, with little (that's not to say no") room for variation. Cover your flanks
date: spend your action points carefully and make sure you leave your outward-facing dudes in overwatch mode.\n\nSo
hoursPlayed: but I was expecting a lot more out of a modern re-vamp of a twenty-four-year-old board game. An XP system to improve my marines would be nice
voteText: and needn't be very complicated to be very satisfying (something along the lines of small accuracy bumps or die-roll bonuses). Some variation in units (both friendly and enemy) would also have been nice.\n\nWhile I do recommend this game

reviewText:
Space Hulk started life as a table top board game where heavily armoured Terminator marines from the Warhammer 40,000 universe, pitted themselves against the multi-clawed Genestealers aboard massive drifting freighters known as Hulks. The tight corridors meant it turned into a battle of the strong and slow versus the quick and deadly.

Space Hulk has been adapted in video game form before in two titles that tried to merge action with semi-turn based gameplay. Now we have a new version of the game which takes a different approach and tries to replicate the board game in a much more precise and faithful way.

At this point I feel it's fair to share with you all that we are pretty well acquainted with the board game and we like it a lot. Its important to bring this up as its likely to have a fairly large bearing on if you are going to like this. Its clear the developers had a specific target audience in mind and there are few concessions to people expecting something similar to the last couple of PC games.

Space Hulk is turn based and relies on dice rolls to carry out actions. At the start of each turn you can move your terminators and set them to guard or go into over watch to scan for enemy movement. At the end of the turn the Genestealers then do the same. Firing weapons and close combat is carried out on the role of dice which means that there is a certain random element to it. This can be frustrating when you are one dice roll away from the success or failure but sound strategy and careful planning does tend to weigh the odds in your favour.

You are going to have to plan you moves carefully as the terminators only have four action points and even turning to face a certain direction requires the use of them. The game is also pretty tough and on the normal setting it took a number of attempts to even get through the second tutorial level. A single mistake of movement can spell disaster in a mission stretching into an hour of more in length so it is advised to save often.

As such, the game plays out more like a slow and thoughtful game of chess than an all guns blazing space shooter, but it certainly draws you in. The presentation is basic and the first thing youll likely do is head to the menu to turn off the shoulder cameras and death animations. Your next step will be to set movement to the fastest setting or youll be playing this until the rapture.

However, once youve got that simple top down/isometric view, the sound of the engines and the cries of victory or defeat coming from your marines it all starts to click and draw you in. It feels claustrophobic and dangerous and the fact a wrong move is so costly certainly adds buckets of tension and atmosphere. A cry of Bolter Jammed" has never caused such terror.

The levels are mainly based on the original games maps and as such it brings a wonderful authenticity for anyone not wanting to pay the huge sum of money required to find a decent condition version of the table top game. There are a few weapons and tricks taken from the Deathwing and Genestealer expansions but we would have liked to see a bit more of this added to give some variety as the game progressed.

Multiplayer is also here and there is a hot seat option to allow players to take turns on the same device. Its a little unwieldy for the Genestealer player but it does work once you get the hang of it. Weirdly
date: you have to play through the main campaign to unlock levels in multiplayer which is something the game could really have done without. Its not as gratifying as it should be
recommended: which is a shame as this is one of the key features that should make the game a must have title.\n\nWhat we have is an authentic Space Hulk table top experience with some rough presentation brought to life digitally. Many may be disappointed
hoursPlayed: but fans of the board game will find this really draws you in. Yes

The rule set is also solid and if you want to recreate some table top fun or take on one tough turn based strategy then this is the game for you. Those looking for fast paced action should look to something else to get their kicks.\n\nOverall 7/10"

reviewText:
If you ever played the original board game in the 90's you will really enjoy this! Its almost a direct port from board game to PC.

The only downside I have experienced so far is that there isnt an experience points system like in other games of the genre, I would like to see the oppurtunity to level up my Terminators and increase skills etc but this just isnt included. If your marine dies in one mission, hes ready to use again in the next which really doesnt help with continuity. Treat each mission as a standalone as the campaign doesnt really feel quite right.

All being said, I really enjoy it, but room for improvement.

reviewText:
--- Review by Four Paws Sly ---

First Hour - Lots of fun! Having owned pretty much every version of Space Hulk over the years, i'm glad to see its a faithful reproduction of the board game. Managed to complete the tutorial missions during the first hour without any difficulty (having played the board game lots probably helped), but it served its purpose to get me into the game once more after having not played it for years. Had just enough time in the first hour to play the first and well known, Suicide Mission - completed it but lost one team member due to overenthusiastic flaming! Oh well. (Just missed the achievement!)
Overall, i'm looking forward to playing this game more and gunning down xenos from one end of the space hulk to the other.

Fifth Hour - Making steady progress through the first supplied campaign - on the fourth mission. Loving the sound of the assault cannon, very thematic. Generally enjoying the ambience of the game as mentioned earlier, the game feels claustrophobic and very much like the board game I knew and loved. The game has some fun achievements to try and earn if that's your bag.
I like the slow clunky movements the tactical dreadnought armour makes - but if you find it too slow, you can always speed up the animations. Also had a few instances where I misclicked the wrong move - the undo feature on the interface is very useful in that regard.
Also enjoying the ability to view the tactical map (reminds me of the board game even more) and rotate/zoom the view to catch all sorts of interesting angles. Overall, still very much enjoying it.

Tenth Hour - Still finding it enjoyable and about halfway through the first campaign, mining it for achievements, getting one of them took a little while and multiple replays - but yes. Not much else to say. Saw the assault cannon blow up in game by rolling a triple on the dice following a reload. Sad times.

Gameplay - 7 / 10
If you liked the board game (not Death Angel, which is way different) - you'll probably like this game. If you haven't played Space Hulk before and are interested in a slow paced strategy / puzzle game pitting man against ferocious alien - its worth a try.

Music / Sound - 7 / 10
Music is very orchestral and keeps in the theme with the Warhammer 40,000 universe, as do the speeches the marines quote as the move or gun down the enemy. Listening to the Genestealers scream as they get gunned down is very reminiscient of Aliens.

Difficulty - 7 / 10
If you're a veteran of strategy games, this one is reasonably challenging but there are harder games out there. I'm currently playing it on Hard (which gives you timed turns and limited command points) and finding it enjoyable without too much struggle.

Longevity - 7 / 10
As mentioned above, by the tenth hour - I am halfway through the campaign but i've replayed a few levels to get the achievements which means you could probably be this far in perhaps 6 hours or less if achievements don't interest you. Based on my progress, I reckon the game will offer you perhaps 18-20 hours of gaming, not including DLC or replays for achievements.

Overall - First Hour 8/10.
Fifth Hour 8/10
Tenth Hour - 7/10
